articles.headline: Tesla’s Aura Dims as Its Plunging Stock Highlights the Risks It Faces
articles.snippet: Production problems in China and Elon Musk’s pursuit of Twitter are leading investors to wonder whether the electric car company is worth as much as they thought.
articles.abstract: Production problems in China and Elon Musk’s pursuit of Twitter are leading investors to wonder whether the electric car company is worth as much as they thought.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors are reassessing the premise that justified Tesla’s astronomical stock price and made its founder, Elon Musk, the richest person in the world.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing

articles.headline: In Georgia, a G.O.P. Primary Tests the Power of a Trump Vendetta
articles.snippet: Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger is fending off a challenger fueled by Donald J. Trump’s election lies. But do voters still care about 2020 as much as the former president does?
articles.abstract: Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger is fending off a challenger fueled by Donald J. Trump’s election lies. But do voters still care about 2020 as much as the former president does?
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on the midterm primary elections.
articles.byline: By Maya King

articles.headline: Baby Formula Shortage Has an Aggravating Factor: Few Producers
articles.snippet: With just a handful of companies making U.S. infant formula, a shutdown of Abbott’s plant had outsized impact on the supply.
articles.abstract: With just a handful of companies making U.S. infant formula, a shutdown of Abbott’s plant had outsized impact on the supply.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the early 1990s, the nation’s biggest makers of baby formula were under fire.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Madeleine Ngo

articles.headline: How a French Bank Captured Haiti
articles.snippet: It helped finance the Eiffel Tower as it drained millions from Haiti. The bank, C.I.C., won’t talk about it, but The Times tracked how much its investors made — and what Haiti lost.
articles.abstract: It helped finance the Eiffel Tower as it drained millions from Haiti. The bank, C.I.C., won’t talk about it, but The Times tracked how much its investors made — and what Haiti lost.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every sentence of the invitation ended with an inky flourish, a triple loop of calligraphy befitting a night of dinner, dancing and fireworks at Haiti’s national palace.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo, Constant Méheut, Selam Gebrekidan and Catherine Porter

articles.headline: Invade Haiti, Wall Street Urged. The U.S. Obliged.
articles.snippet: The long occupation of Haiti began with a drumbeat from the bank that became Citigroup, decades of diplomatic correspondence and other records show.
articles.abstract: The long occupation of Haiti began with a drumbeat from the bank that became Citigroup, decades of diplomatic correspondence and other records show.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the drowsy hours of a December afternoon, eight American Marines strolled into the headquarters of Haiti’s national bank and walked out with $500,000 in gold, packed in wooden boxes.
articles.byline: By Selam Gebrekidan, Matt Apuzzo, Catherine Porter and Constant Méheut

articles.headline: Demanding Reparations, and Ending Up in Exile
articles.snippet: A firebrand Haitian president tried to hold France to account for its years of exploitation. He soon found himself ousted from power.
articles.abstract: A firebrand Haitian president tried to hold France to account for its years of exploitation. He soon found himself ousted from power.
articles.lead_paragraph: The shock came midway through the speech.
articles.byline: By Constant Méheut, Catherine Porter, Selam Gebrekidan and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: Russia Hustles to Recruit Soldiers and Halts Gas Supplies to Finland
articles.snippet: The war has evolved into something of a stalemate that has seriously depleted Russia’s conventional war capabilities, even as it has made some gains.
articles.abstract: The war has evolved into something of a stalemate that has seriously depleted Russia’s conventional war capabilities, even as it has made some gains.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Russia took new steps on Friday to gird for an escalating struggle with the West over the war in Ukraine, moving to expand military recruitment to older citizens and severing gas supplies to Finland in apparent retaliation for its Nordic neighbor’s application to join the NATO alliance.
articles.byline: By Katrin Bennhold, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: Ginni Thomas Urged Arizona Lawmakers to Overturn Election
articles.snippet: The wife of Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas wrote to legislators in a crucial swing state after the Trump campaign’s loss in 2020.
articles.abstract: The wife of Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas wrote to legislators in a crucial swing state after the Trump campaign’s loss in 2020.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the weeks after the 2020 presidential election, Virginia Thomas, the wife of Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas, twice lobbied the speaker of the Arizona House and another lawmaker to effectively reverse Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s popular-vote victory and deliver the crucial swing state to Donald J. Trump.
articles.byline: By Jo Becker and Danny Hakim

articles.headline: How Jack Welch’s Reign at G.E. Gave Us Elon Musk’s Twitter Feed
articles.snippet: The onetime ‘manager of the century’ paved the way for C.E.O.s to moonlight as internet trolls.
articles.abstract: The onetime ‘manager of the century’ paved the way for C.E.O.s to moonlight as internet trolls.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Jack Welch died on March 1, 2020, tributes poured in for the longtime chief executive of General Electric, whom many revered as the greatest chief executive of all time.
articles.byline: By David Gelles

articles.headline: The Russian Orthodox Leader at the Core of Putin’s Ambitions
articles.snippet: Patriarch Kirill I has provided spiritual cover for the invasion of Ukraine, reaping vast resources for his church in return. Now, in an extraordinary step, the E.U. is threatening him with sanctions.
articles.abstract: Patriarch Kirill I has provided spiritual cover for the invasion of Ukraine, reaping vast resources for his church in return. Now, in an extraordinary step, the E.U. is threatening him with sanctions.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Russia’s invasion of Ukraine unfolded, Patriarch Kirill I, the leader of the Moscow-based Russian Orthodox Church, had an awkward Zoom meeting with Pope Francis.
articles.byline: By Jason Horowitz

articles.headline: Perdue Had Trump. In Georgia, Kemp Had Everything Else.
articles.snippet: David Perdue challenged Gov. Brian Kemp because of Donald Trump’s fury over his 2020 loss. Thoroughly outflanked and failing to gain traction, he is now staring down defeat.
articles.abstract: David Perdue challenged Gov. Brian Kemp because of Donald Trump’s fury over his 2020 loss. Thoroughly outflanked and failing to gain traction, he is now staring down defeat.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on the midterm primary elections.
articles.byline: By Reid J. Epstein and Shane Goldmacher

articles.headline: In the Fight Over How to Teach Reading, This Guru Makes a Major Retreat
articles.snippet: Lucy Calkins, a leading literacy expert, has rewritten her curriculum to include a fuller embrace of phonics and the science of reading. Critics may not be appeased.
articles.abstract: Lucy Calkins, a leading literacy expert, has rewritten her curriculum to include a fuller embrace of phonics and the science of reading. Critics may not be appeased.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, Lucy Calkins has determined how millions of children learn to read. An education professor, she has been a pre-eminent leader of “balanced literacy,” a loosely defined teaching philosophy.
articles.byline: By Dana Goldstein

articles.headline: Lara Logan, Once a Star at CBS News, Is Now One for the Far Right
articles.snippet: The former chief foreign affairs correspondent is now a popular guest on podcasts hosted by vaccine skeptics and deniers of the 2020 election.
articles.abstract: The former chief foreign affairs correspondent is now a popular guest on podcasts hosted by vaccine skeptics and deniers of the 2020 election.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Lara Logan reached the heights of American journalism more than a decade ago, as the chief foreign affairs correspondent for CBS News, her bosses didn’t think twice about sending her to cover the biggest stories in the world. Producers clamored to work with her as she landed interviews with a Taliban commander, chronicled the Arab Spring and tracked the Ebola outbreak. Former President Barack Obama called her to wish her well after the most traumatic event of what seemed like a limitless career: She was sexually assaulted while covering a demonstration in Cairo’s Tahrir Square in 2011.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: ‘Such Bad Guys Will Come’: How One Russian Brigade Terrorized Bucha
articles.snippet: A particularly fearsome unit of Moscow’s invading army arrived in the Kyiv suburb in mid-March. The soldiers’ reputation preceded them.
articles.abstract: A particularly fearsome unit of Moscow’s invading army arrived in the Kyiv suburb in mid-March. The soldiers’ reputation preceded them.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUCHA, Ukraine — When the soldiers of Russia’s 64th Motorized Rifle Brigade arrived in Bucha in mid-March, they brought a new level of death and terror to the city.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Daniel Berehulak

articles.headline: Southern Baptist Leaders Mishandled Sex Abuse Crisis, Report Alleges
articles.snippet: Executives of the nation’s largest Protestant denomination ignored victims, resisted reforms and were concerned with avoiding ‘potential liability,’ the third-party investigation says.
articles.abstract: Executives of the nation’s largest Protestant denomination ignored victims, resisted reforms and were concerned with avoiding ‘potential liability,’ the third-party investigation says.
articles.lead_paragraph: National leaders of the Southern Baptist Convention suppressed reports of sexual abuse and resisted proposals for reform over two decades, according to a third-party investigation published by the convention Sunday. The report also said that a former president of the denomination was accused of sexually assaulting a woman in 2010, a claim the report described as “credible.”
articles.byline: By Ruth Graham and Elizabeth Dias

articles.headline: Kushner’s and Mnuchin’s Quick Pivots to Business With the Gulf
articles.snippet: Weeks before the Trump administration ended, Jared Kushner and Steven Mnuchin met with future investors on official trips to the Middle East.
articles.abstract: Weeks before the Trump administration ended, Jared Kushner and Steven Mnuchin met with future investors on official trips to the Middle East.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shortly before the 2020 election, Trump administration officials unveiled a U.S. government-sponsored program called the Abraham Fund that they said would raise $3 billion for projects around the Middle East.
articles.byline: By Kate Kelly and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Biden Pledges to Defend Taiwan if It Faces a Chinese Attack
articles.snippet: Moving away from a policy of “strategic ambiguity,” the president said that to protect the island democracy, he would go beyond what the U.S. has done for Ukraine.
articles.abstract: Moving away from a policy of “strategic ambiguity,” the president said that to protect the island democracy, he would go beyond what the U.S. has done for Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — President Biden signaled on Monday that he would use military force to defend Taiwan if it were ever attacked by China, dispensing with the “strategic ambiguity” traditionally favored by American presidents, and drawing a firmer line at a time of rising tensions in the region.
articles.byline: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Peter Baker

articles.headline: A Vote by Activision Workers Could Give Unions a Foothold in Gaming
articles.snippet: Employees at a company subsidiary complain about long hours and low pay. On Monday, they could vote to form the first union at a big U.S. gaming company.
articles.abstract: Employees at a company subsidiary complain about long hours and low pay. On Monday, they could vote to form the first union at a big U.S. gaming company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jessica Gonzalez can sometimes still hear the eerie theme music for one of the Call of Duty video games in her mind. She jokes that the soundtrack will play on a loop in her subconscious when she gets older.
articles.byline: By Kellen Browning

articles.headline: Russian-Speaking Technologists Rebuild Their Lives in a San Francisco Home
articles.snippet: They moved from Russia, Ukraine, Belarus and other countries for jobs in the technology industry. Now they are joined by friends fleeing war and repression.
articles.abstract: They moved from Russia, Ukraine, Belarus and other countries for jobs in the technology industry. Now they are joined by friends fleeing war and repression.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Over the past five years, Andrey Doronichev has shared his four-story townhouse with nearly 100 entrepreneurs, investors and other aspiring technologists from countries that were once part of the Soviet Union.
articles.byline: By Cade Metz

articles.headline: The Refinery Standing Between Germany and an Oil Embargo
articles.snippet: A Russian-owned refinery, linked to a Soviet-era pipeline, is a reminder of Germany’s past and a stumbling block to efforts to cut off Russian oil.
articles.abstract: A Russian-owned refinery, linked to a Soviet-era pipeline, is a reminder of Germany’s past and a stumbling block to efforts to cut off Russian oil.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, crude oil piped in from Russia has flowed into a giant refinery in Schwedt, an industrial city on the Oder River in Germany, providing jobs for thousands of workers and a reliable source of gasoline, jet fuel and heating oil for residents of Berlin.
articles.byline: By Melissa Eddy

articles.headline: The Era of Borderless Data Is Ending
articles.snippet: Nations are accelerating efforts to control data produced within their perimeters, disrupting the flow of what has become a kind of digital currency.
articles.abstract: Nations are accelerating efforts to control data produced within their perimeters, disrupting the flow of what has become a kind of digital currency.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every time we send an email, tap an Instagram ad or swipe our credit cards, we create a piece of digital data.
articles.byline: By David McCabe and Adam Satariano
